This would be displayed when the cart is empty but there is no redirect for some reason.

For example, if there is a cart error message and the cart is empty, the redirect will not happen. Currently this means the user will see the (dismissible) error message but the page will remain in a "loading" state forever.

When a redirect payment method (eg: PayPal) returns you to the checkout page because the payment was cancelled or failed, any form data entered in the payment method step will be empty again. This can be particularly annoying for payment methods that require a lot of that data, like the form for credit cards in Brazil (Ebanx), or the form for Netbanking in India.

This does not include the form fields in the contact details step, as those are preserved when you submit the payment, even if it fails (they are sent to the transaction endpoint on WPCOM and there they update the "cached domain contact" data which is later fetched by checkout when it reloads).

Originally reported by @nbloomf 

Update: originally I believed this was also the case for contact details, but I have proven that it is not.

Mailchimp is going to break November 10.

They are introducing a static direct matching of our `callback_url` passed in the Oauth proces.
https://www.oauth.com/oauth2-servers/redirect-uris/redirect-uri-registration/


The problem is that `Keyring_Service_OAuth1` class generates `callback_url` that has nonces and other dynamic parameters:


```
		$this->callback_url = Keyring_Util::admin_url(
			$this->get_name(),
			array(
				'action'   => 'verify',
				'kr_nonce' => $kr_nonce,
				'nonce'    => $nonce,
			)
		);
```

Exact matching will naturally not handle these parameters correctly.

Previously the matching was fuzzy, so the parameters were passed through, but now when parameters are part of exact matching, the oauth connections will fail.

## What needs to be done:

1. Rewrite `Keyring_Service_Mailchimp` to pass this data in `state` parameter, how it's supposed to be done in Oauth. It may be prudent to do so in a reusable way - the same limitation prevented me from implementing Constant Contact back in the day. Make sure the redirect_url is the same every time.
1. Update the Mailchimp app on the mailchimp side - it's under my account - credentials in secret store `4668`

#### Steps to reproduce 1. Go to WordPress.com > My Site > Posts > Add new post. 1. Add a paragraph block and change the color for it in the block settings. 1. Add a paragraph with "Align text left". 1. Add a paragraph with "Align text center". 1. Add a paragraph with "Align text right". 1. Publish the post. 1. View the post in the Reader and check to see if the paragraph alignment looks correct. #### What I expected I expected that centered text would appear center-aligned in the Reader. #### What happened instead No alignment options are respected in the Reader. #### Browser / OS version * Safari 13.1.1 on macOS 10.15.4 * Safari iOS 13.6 on iPhone 11 * WPiOS 15.5.01 on iPhone 11 #### Screenshot / Video Web|Reader web|Reader mobile web|Reader iOS app Dark Mode ---|---|---|--- ||![IMG_4513](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1119271/90530469-2a267800-e132-11ea-9f2d-9a24d967ff98.png)|![IMG_4515](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1119271/90530480-2c88d200-e132-11ea-93ab-e3b75b8da866.png) * Web: https://made4testing0318.blog/2020/08/18/paragraph-color-alignment/ * Reader: https://wordpress.com/read/feeds/96421692/posts/2866304892 #### Context / Source In mobile support, we have observed that users have asked for text alignment and colors to be respected in the Reader. We discussed which of those things should be respected in an intentionally style-neutral environment such as the Reader at https://github.com/wordpress-mobile/WordPress-iOS/issues/13930#issuecomment-615465956 and the consensus was that we should not support color changes in the Reader but we are open to supporting alignment. In another `wp-calypso` issue at https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/issues/43595#issuecomment-653341158, it was suggested that headings should be displayed with the correct size and alignment, but not colors, to respect some styles the content creator has added while still keeping the Reader's look. In my experience talking with users, centering would be the most wanted. From a maintenance perspective, I can see not supporting only center-aligned text because left-aligned or right-aligned text could change the flow of the document in unexpected ways. Centered text does seem to be a use case that could benefit the fundamental reading flow of a document without unwanted side effects, and this also applies (probably more strongly) to other blocks such as buttons, quotes, and images. My recommendation would be to support centering and it's up to you which blocks should support center-alignment and which should not—for example, you could decide to allow centering to work for buttons, quotes, and images but not for paragraphs. #perspective #manual-testing #user-report

The Gutenboarding design screen features several _Starter Designs_ that are not available to users right now outside of this experimental flow.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/545779/89432620-f5b0c600-d706-11ea-9852-877ef203798d.png)

These Starter Designs are not just _Themes_. A Starter Design is …

1. A Theme selection.
2. The page content.
3. The font settings.

Here's an illustration.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/545779/89432816-2c86dc00-d707-11ea-9fde-11a47662ab1f.png)

Those three sites use the Mayland theme. The first two sites are Starter Designs. The third one is the demo site displayed in the theme showcase. 

This issue proposes we modify the Theme Showcase and the necessary APIs to add those Starter Designs to our Theme Showcase.

The end result, visually, would be something like this illustration from @alaczek.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/545779/89435440-791fe680-d70a-11ea-922a-a64c79dc44e8.png)

In this illustration Starter Designs sit alongside Themes and Theme Demo sites. This would likely open up several new possibilities for theme variety, HE support, site creation, bundling of features, etc.

I believe this would require the following changes to the Blog that powers the Showcase. We would likely require some new Taxonomies to be registered alongside the existing ones.

- Theme name
- Font settings
- Demo site URL
- Screenshot

The API would look for those taxonomies. When they **do not exist** the API would fall back to it's current status quo of "not worrying" about that and displaying demos, screenshots, and sites, and activating themes based on the theme slug.

**If they do exist** …
- the Theme Showcase would display any supplied URL or screenshot for a "demo site"
- and the API would then set the supplied font styles along with the correct theme on theme switch.

The end result would be seeing arbitrary designs in the theme showcase “constructed” out of multiple themes, homepages, and font styles.

When you pick one of those designs you get the theme and the font styles applied to your site.

cc @iamtakashi @rickybanister @kjellr

#### Steps to reproduce

1. Starting on a codebase using `wpcalypso/react`
2. In a new file, add the following:
```js
/**
 * WordPress dependencies
 */
import { __ } from '@wordpress/i18n';

export default {
...
```
3. This triggers `wpcalypso/import-docblock`, even though there are no other imports in the file, so we cannot have external or internal import docblocks (or they'd be empty).

I think it would make sense to update the rule to have it look for "WordPress dependencies" as well, since those can now be valid imports, on their own within a file.

Related discussion:

This is a general issue to investigate optimising the page layout picker (starter page templates) modal across a number of areas. It will depend on Patterns API work, so the scope of this will likely change.

* [ ] The page layout picker currently loads the page templates server-side via an API call and attaches them to the initial page load in [the `starterPageTemplatesConfig` object](https://github.com/automattic/wp-calypso/blob/2b83937b085691ba66d162c35ca4a28ff48a5ce4/apps/full-site-editing/full-site-editing-plugin/starter-page-templates/class-starter-page-templates.php#L181). Right now this is adding around 463kb to our initial page load for the editor when loading it with the page layout picker.
  - Explore lazy-loading this template data after the initial page load
  - Can we move to having two API calls, one to get the list of available page layouts (similar to how we list available designs in Gutenboarding), and one to grab the block markup for _just_ the selected page layout? This should support having a growing list of available page layouts, without slowing down the initial page load or browsing page layouts
* [ ] When the list of available page layouts is first rendered ([renderTemplatesList](https://github.com/automattic/wp-calypso/blob/39ed68c25110278412f8dfa753e99562dd84beab/apps/full-site-editing/full-site-editing-plugin/starter-page-templates/page-template-modal/index.js#L317)) , the memoized function [`getBlocksByTemplateSlugs` is called](https://github.com/automattic/wp-calypso/blob/39ed68c25110278412f8dfa753e99562dd84beab/apps/full-site-editing/full-site-editing-plugin/starter-page-templates/page-template-modal/index.js#L57) — this is a computationally expensive function that iterates through all of the loaded templates and parses the blocks. However, we probably only need to parse blocks when we wish to preview or use them — can this logic be moved to occur only when a user selects a particular layout?  This might help performance on low-powered devices / older browsers
* [ ] Previews — currently the thumbnail previews are static images, and the larger preview is using a `<BlockEditorProvider>` and `<BlockList>` to [render the preview](https://github.com/automattic/wp-calypso/blob/34169f274c2191623f333824ecbe4b8835bc6ea3/apps/full-site-editing/full-site-editing-plugin/starter-page-templates/page-template-modal/components/block-preview.js#L31) from an array of blocks. This approach mirrors Gutenberg's [`<BlockPreview>` component](https://github.com/wordpress/gutenberg/blob/153817e3493e5ca3518f913d9ff859aab6e9a3e4/packages/block-editor/src/components/block-preview/index.js#L35), but is this the best way to go about previewing a block pattern / page layout? The current approach isn't _just_ previewing content, it's doing a fair bit more as revealed in the bug in #44038. Is it possible for us to use pre-rendered markup in our previews, similar to how the template/demo endpoint is used in Gutenboarding? E.g. could we use mShots for the thumbnail screenshots, and that endpoint for the larger preview?
  - Explore whether or not using something like the `template/demo` endpoint would result in better performance for the larger preview
  - Explore how feasible it would be to use mShots to generate preview thumbnails of the page layouts (the page layouts rendered in the context of the current theme)

fetch and fetchNextPage

Both of these track whether "fetching" is ongoing. To make fetch happen, we'll add a new reducer called fetching which will manage state shaped like so:

```ts type Fetching = { [siteId: number]: { nextPage: boolean, items: { [itemId: (string|number)]: boolean } } } ```

The reducer will listen for the following actions:

  1. MEDIA_ITEM_REQUEST
    • Action will have site id and item id. Set state[ siteId ].items[ mediaId ] = true
  2. MEDIA_ITEM_REQUEST_FAILURE/MEDIA_ITEM_REQUEST_SUCCESS
    • Action will have site id and item id. Omit the item id from the items for the site.
  3. MEDIA_REQUEST
    • Action will have just a site id. Set state[ siteId ].nextPage = true
  4. MEDIA_REQUEST_FAILURE/MEDIA_REQUEST_SUCCESS
    • Action will have site id. Set nextPage back to false for the site.

Actions already exist for all of these.

Then we can write thunks for fetch and fetchNextPage which will follow the same "flux adapter" pattern as add, update, and edit media have so far.

fetch

  1. Check if already fetching and escape if so
  2. Dispatch requestMediaItem
  3. Do the request
  4. On error dispatch failMediaItemRequest; on success dispatch successMediaItemRequest

fetchNextPage

  1. Check if already fetching and escape if so
  2. Dispatch requestMedia
  3. Do the request
  4. On error dispatch failMediaRequest; on success dispatch successMediaRequest.

Prepare Calypso for `@wordpress/i18n` and `@automattic/react-i18n` usage.

[Gutenboarding](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/tree/master/client/landing/gutenboarding) ([`/new`](https://wordpress.com/new)) is using `@wordpress/i18n` for static localization and [`@automattic/react-i18n`](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/master/packages/react-i18n/) package for reactive localization in React.

CompositeCheckout currently uses its [own reactive implementation](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/3be85c54c1f2f4291e8a2dea0177fe7d1a98f043/packages/composite-checkout/src/lib/localize.js) based on `@wordpress/i18n`. Calypso-wide support for `@automattic/react-i18n` would allow CompositeCheckout to share the implementation used in Gutenboarding and ideally across other projects. See #42831.

Much of this could likely be handled by adding a few components designed to specifically for WordPress.com i18n and these i18n libraries.

https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/39627 contains some sketching of components that could be share and serves as a starting point. These were oriented for debugging and testing, but the ideas hold.

## Components



### `<CalypsoI18n />`

This would be a top level component. It could handle translation fetching and updating, render an `<I18nProvider />`, and render any necessary translation effect handlers:

https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/5c77aa4a2310d6d0ba4fb2fb1cc74db7aecc81f3/client/landing/gutenboarding/index.tsx#L130-L155

### `<CalypsoI18nDomEffects />`

Handle updating `lang/dir` in the DOM.

https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/5c77aa4a2310d6d0ba4fb2fb1cc74db7aecc81f3/client/landing/gutenboarding/index.tsx#L157-L164


Related: I18n issues in the Gutenboarding: https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/issues/37665

#### Suggested change

Allow setting the initial option for choosing a page as static “Homepage” when the site is set to show the latest posts as the homepage.

#### Context

We want to empower site authors to not need the Customizer to build their site quickly and easily from Calypso.

We want to make sure they can learn via hints in the UI, and be empowered to make changes themselves.

#### The Issue

In the default state, WordPress.com sites show the blog feed as the homepage.

The following is what shows up in Site > Pages area in Calypso:

![screen-shot-2020-03-02-at-07 45 12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/66797/81457387-b2b47600-914a-11ea-90d7-eff9c0a97263.png)

Item A on the screenshot takes you to the front-end of the site. As a user, I might assume that this takes me somewhere I can change this behavior and set an actual landing page as the homepage, — **but it doesn’t**.

![screen-shot-2020-03-02-at-09 02 06](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/66797/81457488-1ccd1b00-914b-11ea-9029-993c90e92cab.png)

If I want to change this… where do I go?

Answer A: Create a new page, and call it “Home”? Nope.
Answer B: Click on that icon A on the screenshot? Nope.
Answer C: Click on the three dots on the page I added to my site, and look for an option to “Set as homepage”, and use that to change this? Nope:

#### Question/Request

If not just placing the controls into the Pages contextual menu — even in the default state — suggest making at least a usability change.

Could we link to the appropriate section in the Customizer right here? Using the wording “Front page is showing your latest posts” to provide the link. Similar to what we have in My Home for editing menus.

Props @davipontesblog for starting this idea.

I don’t think this will solve all the confusion about having posts in the homepage or a static page, and this might not be an issue in the future as having posts in your homepage might rely entirely on static pages with a Posts block, but, for now, it could save a lot of headache and churn (“I wanted a website, not a blog!” said a frustrated user every once in a while in chat).

Thanks for considering!

After a domain is mapped and the DNS is changed to point to WordPress.com, it can be confusing for users to still see the `.wordpress.com` domain for their site.

We should add a Customer Home notification/prompt when the system detects that a mapped domain is now loading the WordPress.com site.

Currently, it's possible to have a primary domain that does *not* load the WordPress.com site. This can cause problems and confusion for users who believe the domain is properly mapped or loading the site, when in fact the domain is pointing elsewhere.

Requiring WordPress.com name servers or A records for a domain to be primary helps reduce this confusion.

This relates to the Starter Page Layouts/Templates feature of the Full Site Editing Plugin.

For context please see:

* https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/issues/39293
* https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/39830

It was determined that the "missing blocks" warning was showing for certain Templates, when the site in question didn't have all the necessary Blocks required by/used in that Template.

A [temporary solution was added](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/39830) to remove any Templates which containing unsupported blocks (via detecting the `core/missing` Block type).

However, other options were suggested as more appropriate solutions in the longer term, namely:

* Not hiding Templates with unsupported Blocks
* Showing an unclickable "ghosted" version of the Template with a prompt to install missing Blocks required by the Template.

This only applies to environments where Plugins can be uninstalled/deactivated.

Challenges in the above approach include:

* Detecting which Blocks are missing - it's easy to detect the `core/missing` type but harder to determine what the original Block that was missing was.
* Determining which Blocks are provided by which Plugins - for example some Blocks come from Plugins which contain many Blocks (eg: FSE, Newspack), others from standalone Plugins (eg: `layout/grid`). Knowing which Plugin needs to be installed to provide which Block is difficult.
* Plugin "install on demand" mechanic - I'm not aware of anywhere where this is in place. We would need to be able to install a Plugin

This issue describes a simple UI fix to make the "Continue as..." login option much more obvious to returning users. **Steps to repeat:** 1. When redirected from a Calypso URL with a site slug on the end, we offer a link to that site's frontend. 2. However, if your login cookie is stale or non-existent, you might end up on a prompt to re-login again to create a fresh login cookie and start a new session. 3. This means Calypso recognizes you, but you have to re-authenticate The action we want users to take 99% of the time is click "Continue as me" in the small text below the header so they can skip login and continue as the current user. **That small text is easy to miss.** Technical note: I believe when 2FA is on for a user account you won't see this "Continue As" screen. **Screenshot** As 3rd party cookies behavior changes in Chrome and Safari, more people will this screen. **Suggested change** 1. Swap the title and the login link 2. Result is "Continue as ..." is the primary option. Large header, all clickable as a big link. 3. The "Log in to your account" below that is the smaller, secondary option. **Code reference** https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/master/client/blocks/login/ — look for `continue-as-user.jsx` and related stylesheet. A user reported concern and confusion after getting the "E-mail login link" notification. This notification is sent after someone logs in to a WordPress.com account with a magic link, and in most cases after intentionally logging in the notification should be clear.

However, in some cases it isn't obvious that a magic link was used. We use magic links in some of our marketing emails, so that when someone clicks the link they are magically logged in and can take an action on their account/site. The login aspect of those links is not transparent, though, so the resulting notification can be confusing or scary. (It's hard to identify the connection between clicking the link in the marketing email and the login notification.)

#### Proposed enhancement

The notification itself can be very alarming, especially if you didn't know you were logged in with a magic link. @koke suggested (and I agree) that adding more context to the notification about when/where the login happened could help:

> Something that could be useful is what other apps do: adding more information about time, browser/device, and approximate location of the login, so it’s easier for them to recognize if it was them or not.

An alternate suggestion from @koke could be to focus on logins from unfamiliar devices/locations, although that might take more backend changes to properly identify:

> Maybe the ‘e-mail login link’ part of the copy is also a bit confusing, and we could just say something like “Someone logged into your account from a browser/device we haven’t seen before…”

**Goal**
Refine the Gutenberg top bar. It's important we keep the top bar clear, and concise so users know it is solely used for high level document management. If we allow any UI component in the top bar it will degrade the experience to the point that the top bar loses value, and importance. By cleaning up the noise in the top bar, creating guidelines, make things contextual, and introducing mechanisms that will keep the order, we can ensure that the top bar component will continue to evolve in a self sustaining way.

**Description**
The top bar is an important component in the Gutenberg editor experience. It contains contains document-level actions like Editor mode, save status, global actions for undo/redo/insert, the settings toggle, and publish options.

As the editor, and Gutenberg continues to expand, we need to keep the top bar free from unnecessary UI components—from core, and 3rd party plugins— that reduce its importance. 

With dotcom buidling a custom editor based off core gutenberg parts, we can improve the UX, serving a stronger, more streamlines exp.

Let's allow folks to search for a setting or action to perform. We'll approach this in two steps. 

First, let's embed the [help FAB](https://a.cl.ly/v1uDOXZ5) directly on My Home:

After this is done (probably in another Issue/PR), let's revive @ramonjd's [PR](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/31903) which included helpful hints for where to find things. We'll need to make sure we can translate it somehow.

I'm pretty sure this has been come up before, but the cropped thumbnail has become a really frustrating part of editing experience now that we provide the user with pre-built page layouts that the images on them are meant to be replaced by them.

For example, you want to replace the three images on a layout that you chose.

![Screenshot 2020-01-15 at 14 12 24](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/908665/72440723-4976b480-37a1-11ea-96a0-0089a26bc51a.png)

In most cases, the pattern would look better if all the three images are the same orientation. **But with the cropped thumbnail you can't tell if the image in the library is portrait or landscape until you add to the page,** and you could easily end up with like this:

Follow up to #37618 and #37640.

Currently, the front page settings are handled in 3 different places:
- wp-admin (Settings -> Reading)
- Customizer (Homepage Settings)
- Calypso Pages list (from each page action menu)

The wp-admin and Customizer implementation is the same, and consists in a two-steps choice:
- Set the homepage to show the latest posts
- Or set it to show a static page
  - Pick a page for the front page
  - Pick a _different_ page for the posts page

Technically these settings are backed by 3 sites options:
- `show_on_front` (can be `posts` or `page`)
- `page_on_front` (front page ID, or `0`)
- `page_for_posts` (posts page ID, or `0`)

With a static front page (`show_on_front = 'page'`), `page_on_front` and `page_for_posts` **cannot** be the same page, because then the meaning would be exactly the same as having the latest posts as homepage (`show_on_front = 'page'`).

While working on #37640, @vindl suggested to allow setting the same page both as front page and posts page.
The approach could be summarized like this:

> If a user, on a site with static front page (`get_option( 'show_on_front' ) === 'page'`), sets the same page as both Front and Posts page (`get_option( 'page_on_front' ) === get_option( 'page_for_posts' )`), we automatically turn the site back to the "Your homepage displays: Your latest posts" option (`get_option( 'show_on_front' ) = 'posts'`).

I agree with the approach, but since this is slightly different than what Core offers, I guess we should discuss it first.

#### Problem
ESLint is currently taking a long time to run (~4 minutes on my machine). cc @blowery

#### Environment Information
This likely does not have an impact on this issue, but leaving this for completeness:

**OS**: macOS 10.14.6
**Node**: v12.11.1
**npm**: v6.12.0

#### Steps to reproduce
1. Clone `Automattic/wp-calypso`
2. Run `npm install`
3. Run `npm run lint:js`

#### Performance Analysis
ESLint will generate a report of the top ten longest-running rules when run with the `TIMING=1` environment variable (see documentation [here](https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/working-with-rules#per-rule-performance)). Here is the report generated for `master`:

```
Rule                              | Time (ms) | Relative
:---------------------------------|----------:|--------:
import/no-extraneous-dependencies | 42270.496 |    39.7%
import/no-nodejs-modules          | 30388.073 |    28.5%
react/no-deprecated               | 10202.986 |     9.6%
react/no-string-refs              |  4528.707 |     4.2%
react/prefer-es6-class            |  3550.438 |     3.3%
no-unused-vars                    |  2469.957 |     2.3%
valid-jsdoc                       |   972.121 |     0.9%
no-regex-spaces                   |   546.561 |     0.5%
jest/no-identical-title           |   441.417 |     0.4%
react-hooks/rules-of-hooks        |   397.941 |     0.4%
```

Roughly 50% of the current run is being eaten up by two rules from the `eslint-plugin-import` plugin (percentages below are out of the total time spent executing rules):

- `import/no-extraneous-imports` is ~40%
- `import/no-nodejs-modules` is ~29%

Disabling these rules cuts the run time down from ~4m to ~2m on my machine (with a fresh run after deleting the cache). I’ve never used these two rules myself and I’m not finding much when I try to Google/GitHub Search for others who have ran into this issue.

#### Possible solutions
1. Disable the two rules. This obviously isn't ideal, but it might be useful to re-evaluate what problem these rules are trying to solve and if it's worth the trade-off of the longer linting run.
1. Spend some time digging into the rules and seeing if we can submit some performance optimization patches upstream. My (naive) guess is that these rules are slower because they are doing file I/O operations.
1. Use editor integrations or a Git commit hook that only runs on staged files for linting in dev and run the full linting job in CI. It looks like there is already a hook, but this wouldn't work right now because there are errors in `master`. However, if those were cleaned up, this could be a good balance of ensuring that all the rules are run on the whole codebase while not lowering the velocity of the local dev environment too much. There would still be a bottleneck at the CI run step, but I personally have found that not to be as much of a hindrance in the projects I've worked on.

Currently, the Full Site Editing's Main Navigation block doesn't have any styling options (except the wide/full block width), and simply reuses the theme CSS `.main-navigation` class styles.

We should keep the theme CSS as default and fallback, but also let the user set their own styling options.

Currently, the Full Site Editing's Site Description block doesn't have any styling options (except the wide/full block width), and simply reuses the theme CSS `.site-description` class styles.

We should keep the theme CSS as default and fallback, but also let the user set their own styling options, like they already do for other blocks like Heading or Paragraph.

In particular we should allow:
- Text alignment (not the same as "block alignment", e.g. wide/full).
- Font size (predefined list and custom).
- Text color (theme palette and custom).
- Background color (theme palette and custom).

And we should prevent:
- Markup (unsupported by default in the site description).
- Multiline (hitting enter should create and focus a paragraph after the block).

Currently, the Full Site Editing's Site Title block doesn't have any styling options (except the wide/full block width), and simply reuses the theme CSS `.site-title` class styles.

We should keep the theme CSS as default and fallback, but also let the user set their own styling options, like they already do for other blocks like Heading or Paragraph.

In particular we should allow:
- Text alignment (not the same as "block alignment", e.g. wide/full).
- Font size (predefined list and custom).
- Text color (theme palette and custom).
- Background color (theme palette and custom).

And we should prevent:
- Markup (unsupported by default in the site title).
- Multiline (hitting enter should create and focus a paragraph after the block).

#### The Problem

Sometimes, images aren't correctly imported during the import process. 

When this happens, images will often _appear_ to have imported over correctly due to the fact posts will reference images from the old hosting. The images will then appear to _disappear_ when the old hosting expires.

An example of this happening can be found in p2EDhh-R5-p2. The user moved to WP.com from Le Monde's blog service, after Le Monde announced it was closing. Everything appeared to be working correctly until Le Monde completely deleted all content that had previously been hosted with them. The user now has no way to recover all of their missing images.  

#### A Possible Solution

It may be helpful to display a dismissible warning in the editor if there’s more than one hot-linked image in a post. This warning would inform users that the images referenced in their post aren't actually present in their site's Media Library.

Such a warning may prompt users to get in touch sooner, while their old sites are still online and we're able to better help them recover the images.

Reported in https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/34997#issuecomment-517325918 If I add a block with background color it will not be rendered properly on the front end: In Editor: On Front End: --- [Palettes in Gutenberg](https://developer.wordpress.org/block-editor/developers/themes/theme-support/#block-color-palettes) needs to be defined both in PHP and CSS to work. In PHP we basically create the colors definitions, that will be eventually used in the editor and to generate some CSS classes (e.g. the `red` color will be applied to a block as the `.has-red-color` class). While Gutenberg uses the hex code provided in PHP, the front end is not aware of it, and only relies on those CSS classes. Of course, though, themes nest those classes inside the post content class. See for example Modern Business: https://github.com/Automattic/themes/blob/04f46cd956e06ab10aa787b7eca08c21075050c0/modern-business/sass/blocks/_blocks.scss Try searching for `.has-primary-color`, and notice how everything is nested inside `.entry .entry-content`. We use the [User lib](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/master/client/lib/user/user.js) to [fetch](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/master/client/lib/user/user.js#L136) user data.

`User.get()` triggers a fetch, but will return whatever user data it has cached, which, if the server hasn't responded or there is not yet any user data, will be false or falsely.

There are a [couple](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/34648#discussion_r305514376) of [instances](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/blob/f5f5035bfa3ef329d4eda27c841f809e9e37647b/client/state/jetpack-connect/actions.js#L378) where we need this user data to complete an operation. 

The workaround has been to poll (via `setInterval`) the user endpoint until the server responds with something useful.

To avoid having to do this, we would benefit from modifying the fetch method, or adding a method to the interface that returns a Promise.

Props to @jsnmoon for 🤔 [about this.](https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/34648#discussion_r305514376
)

It's not recommended for bloggers to add more than 15 categories and tags (combined) to their posts, as per [our public documentation](https://en.support.wordpress.com/topics/#missing-posts): > In most cases, there’s no need to assign more than a handful of tags per post. If you use more than 15 tags and categories (total), your posts will not appear on tag pages (because you don’t want to see irrelevant content showing up there, and neither do we). Bloggers often don't realise that adding more 15 tags and categories will prevent their posts from appearing in the Reader's tag pages, therefore possibly reducing traffic to their content. This is something that's come up in support (most recently in 2152478-zen) but also when visiting posts family or friends have published. It would be great if, when more than 15 categories and tags are detected, a notification popped up in the categories/tags module within the editor: This could potentially reduce some of the confused "missing posts" requests we see in support but also help set bloggers who make this mistake (without ever realising it or contacting support) up for success.

When Blogger plan user tries to map a .com domain (or other "non-.blog" domain) to their site, Personal plan is automatically added at the checkout. This is expected behaviour – since Blogger plan allows .blog domains only.

It would be great if we could display a little message why the Personal plan is added at the checkout.

#### Steps to reproduce
1. Open Calypso on a site with Blogger plan.
2. Navigate to Manage → Domains and add a new "non-.blog" domain (mapped or new).
3. Go through the checkout.

#### What I expected

Personal plan is automatically added and also a message explaining _why_. As a bonus, we could also let the user choose other plan than Personal, e.g. Premium or higher.

#### What happened instead

Personal plan is automatically added without any context information displayed to the user.


#### Context / Source
